All You Can Eat - Cache

Posted on 04-25-2018   |     |   visitors

LRU Cache

https://leetcode.com/problems/lru-cache/description/

HashMap + doublely-linked list

  • double-linked list (prev & next) keeps track of least recent use (front) and most recent use (back)
  • old item in front, new item at the end
  • upon read/update of existing key, perform unlink() and insertTOEnd()
  • unlink() unlink current node from the linkedf list
  • insertTOEnd() insert current node to end of the list
  • freeSpace() evit LRU item from cache

Linked HashMap

ref: https://leetcode.com/problems/lru-cache/discuss/45939/Laziest-implementation:-Java's-LinkedHashMap-takes-care-of-everything

LFU Cache

https://leetcode.com/problems/lfu-cache/description/

  • method1: min-heap + hashtable (timestamp when freq equals)
  • method2: hashtable + doublely linkedlist

Method 1 (O(logN) time, One Hashmap + priority queue)

  • either min-heap/BST to keep track of usage count
  • additional time stamps required when usage count are the same

Method 2 (O(1) time, Two Hashmaps + doublely linked list)

  • lists: Hashmap & List<DoublelyListNode> w/ dummy node in front
  • nodes: Hashmap with key, value pair mapping
  • List<DoublelyListNode> indexed by frequency
  • remove from the back of linked list at min_freq index
  • min records the minimum frequency of all cache entry, increment it when current min‚Äòs list become empty

http://www.cnblogs.com/grandyang/p/6258459.html

LFU Cache in O(1) LeetCode 460 - Ëä±Ëä±ÈÖ±:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MCTN3MM8vHA

Method 3 (O(1) time, Two Hashmaps + double linkedlist) [preferred]
